text: Which package folks here use for running Panel data models in Julia? I had a look at `FixedEffectModels.jl` but I want to run swamy-arora random effects estimators and the between estimators, too. For fixed effects this package works awesome though.

elements.text: Which package folks here use for running Panel data models in Julia? I had a look at
FixedEffectModels.jl
but I want to run swamy-arora random effects estimators and the between estimators, too. For fixed effects this package works awesome though.
Probably MixedModels.jl for RE

text: That is useful, and what about pooling OLS?

elements.text: That is useful, and what about pooling OLS?

text: What do you mean by pooling OLS? I use the term "pooled OLS" like Wooldridge does, i.e. basically plain vanilla OLS, but I'm aware that there are different definitions for what fixed and random effects mean across fields, so maybe there's something more to pooling OLS?

elements.text: What do you mean by pooling OLS? I use the term "pooled OLS" like Wooldridge does, i.e. basically plain vanilla OLS, but I'm aware that there are different definitions for what fixed and random effects mean across fields, so maybe there's something more to pooling OLS?

text: If it's just OLS like in Wooldridge then you can do it with any package - GLM, or FixedEffectModels (just don't add fixed effects to your formula), MixedModels...

elements.text: If it's just OLS like in Wooldridge then you can do it with any package - GLM, or FixedEffectModels (just don't add fixed effects to your formula), MixedModels...

text: Econometrics.jl has fixed effects, between, and Swamy-Arora random effects.

elements.text: Econometrics.jl has fixed effects, between, and Swamy-Arora random effects.

text: MixedModels.jl random effects is a different estimator. That’s the statistics / psych flavor, not the economics one. Different approach to error decomposition.

elements.text: MixedModels.jl random effects is a different estimator. That’s the statistics / psych flavor, not the economics one. Different approach to error decomposition.

text: Pooled estimator differs in the time variant sense that those operations are done on a per panel basis. The fixed effects is the same as the Least Square Dummy Variable (LSDV) except for the covariance estimators which need to account for the sampling design (this is mostly a core issue in random effects stats vs random effects econ).

elements.text: Pooled estimator differs in the time variant sense that those operations are done on a per panel basis. The fixed effects is the same as the Least Square Dummy Variable (LSDV) except for the covariance estimators which need to account for the sampling design (this is mostly a core issue in random effects stats vs random effects econ).

text: True fixed effects are not consistently estimated due to the curse of dimensionality. However, for large number of controls, it is more efficient to absorb them rather than estimate those parameters normally.

elements.text: True fixed effects are not consistently estimated due to the curse of dimensionality. However, for large number of controls, it is more efficient to absorb them rather than estimate those parameters normally.

text:
<@U82LX4ACB> I was using Econometrics.jl only at first, but it was showing me this weird error.
*`MethodError: no method matching isordered(::PooledArrays.PooledArray{String,UInt32,1,Array{UInt32,1}})`*

Nut when I used FixedEffectModels.jl, it worked fine. I am not sure what this error was for, and everything in the dataset seems fine, too.

elements.text: I was using Econometrics.jl only at first, but it was showing me this weird error.
MethodError: no method matching isordered(::PooledArrays.PooledArray{String,UInt32,1,Array{UInt32,1}})
Nut when I used FixedEffectModels.jl, it worked fine. I am not sure what this error was for, and everything in the dataset seems fine, too.

text: That is a known issue. I was still waiting on issue being fixed at the source so I can upstream it. Basically, just make sure that data uses `CategoricalVector` instead of `PooledArray`.

elements.text: That is a known issue. I was still waiting on issue being fixed at the source so I can upstream it. Basically, just make sure that data uses
CategoricalVector
instead of
PooledArray
